author: Mark Moore
title: Gorsuch declines to weigh in on Trump’s travel ban | New York Post
text:
Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch on Tuesday declined to weigh in on the legality of President Trump’s travel ban but said the Constitution protects religious freedom.
“We have a free exercise clause that protects the free exercise of religious liberty by all persons in this country,” Gorsuch said during his confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee. “If you’re asking me how I apply it to a specific case, I can’t talk about that for understandable reasons.”
Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) asked him to respond to comments from a Republican lawmaker that Trump’s immigration ban would be safe if Gorsuch was confirmed.
“Senator, he has no idea how I’d rule in that case and, Senator, I’m not going to say anything here that would give anybody any idea how I’d rule in any case like that that cold come before the Supreme Court,” he said.
“It would be a violation of the separation of powers and judicial independence if someone sitting at this table in order to get confirmed had to make promises or commitments about how they would rule in a case that’s currently pending and likely to make its way to the Supreme Court,” Gorsuch added.
On travel ban, Neil Gorsuch says: “I’m not going to say anything here that would give anybody any idea how I’d rule in any case like that.” pic.twitter.com/qUrS6ebfbk 
— ABC News Politics (@ABCPolitics) March 21, 2017 
Pushed further by Leahy about the White House’s comments that Trump’s orders on national security were above judicial review, Gorsuch said, “No man is above the law.”
Leahy asked if there should be a “religious test” in the United States.
“That would be inappropriate, yes,” Gorsuch said, adding “It’s against the law.”
He assured the senators that anybody coming to his court would get a fair shake.
“Anyone, any law is going to get a fair square deal with me. My job is to treat every litigant as I would wish to be treated,” he said.
Trump’s travel ban, which severely restricts immigration from targeted mainly Muslim countries, has been blocked by the courts .
